case_vignette: Three days after undergoing open surgery to repair a bilateral inguinal hernia, a 66-year-old man has new, intermittent upper abdominal discomfort that worsens when he walks around. He also has new shortness of breath that resolves with rest. There were no complications during surgery or during the immediate postsurgical period. Ambulation was restarted on the first postoperative day. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Prior to admission, his medications included metformin, simvastatin, and lisinopril. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 129/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. The abdomen is soft and shows two healing surgical scars with moderate serous discharge. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG at rest shows no abnormalities. Cardiac enzyme levels are within the reference range. An x-ray of the chest and abdominal ultrasonography show no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Cardiovascular System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having an on-and-off stomachache in the upper part when I walk, and I get out of breath too, but it gets better if I sit down and rest.
How old are you?
I am 66 years old.
Do you have a history of heart problems or high blood pressure?
I have high blood pressure, but no heart problems that I know of.
Do you take any medications for your high blood pressure?
Yes, I take lisinopril for my high blood pressure.
Do you have a family history of heart disease or related conditions?
I'm just a patient and don't have such details to share.
**Final Diagnosis:** Possible Angina due to Coronary Artery Disease
